sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I will begin it in your happy omen:
But firſt confeſſe, that you haue vanquiſht me.
And if I ſhall orecome an enemy,
Yeild you the Trophies of the victory.

sp.speaker: Fauſt.
sp.p: Pleaſe you walke in the while.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I ſhall attend you.
Henceforth I'le ſtriue to flye the ſight of pleaſure,
As of an Harpy or a Baſiliske,
And when ſhe flatters, ſeale my eares with Waxe,
Tooke from that boat, that rowed with a deafe oare,
From the ſweete tunes of the Sicilian ſhoare.

div.stage: Enter Trimalchio, Capritio, Fidelio, Ardelio, Snarle.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Are you for the warre indeed?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Immediately.
Is there any of you will goe along with me,
Beſides this Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Ardelio, thou art my faythfull ſeruant.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: Alaſſe ſir,
My body is fat, and ſpungy, penetrable;
And the leaſt cold will kill mee.

sp.speaker: Snarle.
sp.l: Yet his face
Is hatcht with impudency, threefold thicke.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: I am not for your Trenches, and cold crampes,
Their diſcipline will quickely bring me vnder:
Ile ſtay at home, and looke to your buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Brother Capritìo, what ſay you to it?

sp.speaker: Caprit.
sp.l: Who I? ods lid I am not ſuch an Aſſe,
To goe amongſt them, like your volunteers,
That frighted worſe at home with debt and danger,
Trauell abroad i'th ſummer to ſee ſeruice,
And then come home i'th winter, to drinke Sacke.
I am none of thoſe, i'le hardly truſt my ſelfe
In the Artillery yard, for feare of miſchiefe.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Mr. Trimalehio, you are yong and luſty,
Full of ambitious thoughts.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: 'Tis true indeede,
That I am growne ambitious of honour.
And meane to purchaſe it.

sp.speaker: Snarle.
sp.l: But with no danger
Of life and hope.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: I meane to hazard a limme for it.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: To the Leager,
Vpon the ſame imployment, that Hercules
Did once againſt the Amazons.

sp.speaker: Snarle.
sp.l: And I
Will ſtay at home, and write their annals for them.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Stay all at home, and hug your ignominyes,
And whilſt we ſpoyle the enemy, may you
Be pil'd by pimpes. Cheaters intrench vpon you.
Let Bawds, and their iſſues ioyne with you. Marry
With whores, and let proiectors rifle for you.
And ſo I leaue you.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: We ſhall heare of you,
By the next Caranto, I make no doubt of it.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Brother Capritto, are you well prouided
With ammunition? arm'd Capa pea,
To ſcale the Fort of our Semiramis?

sp.speaker: Capr.
sp.l: I am appoynted, Brother.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Then let vs on,
And beate a parly at the gates. So, ho.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: How now what bold aduenturers be here?
What deſperat rudeneſſe tempts you to your ruine?
Here are no Geeſe to keepe our Capitoll.
But men of armes, you ſlaues, ſtout impes of Mars:
Gyants, ſonnes of the Earth, that ſhall riſe vp,
Like Cadmus progeny, to fight it out,
Till you are all conſumed. Haue you any gold?
Tis that muſt breake our gates ope: there are lockt
A ſcore of Danaes wenches of delight,
Within this Caſtle, if I liſt to ſhew you
Where Circe keepes her reſidence, that ſhall,
If ſhee but lay her rod vpon your necks,
Tranſforme you into Apes, & Swine, you ſheeps face.
If thou ſhal't once but drinke of her inchantments,
Shee'll make a Lyon of thee.

sp.speaker: Caprit.
sp.l: Alaſſe ſir,
I had rather looke like an Aſſe, as I am ſtill.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Bee not too boiſtrous, my ſonne of thunder.
Wee are wel-wiſhers to thy campe, and thee,
Here is a freſhman, I would haue acquainted
With the myſtery of your iniquity.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: I do imbrace thy league, and returne the hand
Of friendſhip. To thy better vnderſtanding,
I will diſcouer the ſituation of the place.
Tis of it ſelfe an Iland, a meere Swans neſt:
Which had Vliſſes ſeene, he would prefer
Before his Ithaca, and he whom Fate
Shall bleſſe to vanquiſh it; Hee may deſerue
The name of a new conquerour. It has
The credit, to bee ſtyl'd the Terra florida,
Of the beſt beautyes in the Towne, my friend,
That repaire hither vpon the leaſt ſummons,
Beſides ſome that are conſtant to their trenches.
Ʋenus in his houſe is predominant.
Tis barren, I confeſſe. Yet wholy giuen
To the deeds of fructication. But thoſe
Are barrd from comming to perfection,
With Rhewmes, and diſeaſes. You Dormiſe,
What muſt I reade a lecture to you gratis?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: No ſir, here's money for you.

sp.speaker: Pander,
sp.l: You may enter,
And returne ſafe, vpon your good behauiour.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: Well, they may talke of Dunkerke, or of Callis,
Enricht with forraine booties, but if euer
A little Garriſon, or ſconce, as this,
Were ſo fild vp with ſpoyles, let me be carted.

sp.speaker: 1. Whore.
sp.l: And carry it ſo cunningly away,
Beyond the reach of Iuſtice, and of all
The iuriſdiction in our owne hand,
Like a free ſtate.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: Did not I purchaſe it?
And am not I the Lady of the Mannor?
And who ſhall dare to queſtion mee? I hope,
I ſhall be able to defend my Fort,
From the inuaſion of the painted ſtaffe,
Or the tempeſtuous paper Engine, ſafe,
As a Moale in a Trench, and worke at hie midnight.
When their wiſe heads are layd, wee'l rayſe the ſpirits
Of our dead pleaſures, vſe the benefit
Of youth, and dance our Orgyes by the Moonelight.

sp.speaker: 1. Whore.
sp.l: I hope they need not to condemne vs, wee driue
As open trade as they, and vent as ill
Commodities, as any: all that we vtter,
Is in darke ſhoppes, or elſe by candlelight.

sp.speaker: 2. Whore.
sp.p: We are become the enuy of Citizens.

sp.speaker: 1. Whore.
sp.p: It is reported that we ſtudy phyſicke.

sp.speaker: 1. Whore.
sp.l: The reaſon is, becauſe we know
The ſeuerall conſtitutions of mens bodies.

sp.speaker: 2. Whore.
sp.p: And ſome tearme vs the Leager▪

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: We defye
The force of any man, who's that knocks ſo?
Go bid the watch looke out, and if their number
Be not too plurall, then let them come in.
But if they chance to bee thoſe ruffian Souldiers,
Let fall the purcullis. All they can do,
Is to diſcharge a volley of oathes at me.
Ile take no tickets, nor no future ſtipends.
Tis not falſe titles, or denominations
Of offices can do it. I muſt haue money.
Tell them ſo, draw the bridge. Ile make them know,
This is no widdowes houſe, but Marcus Manitius,
Is Lord of the Iland, Who waſt?

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: Pox on the Marſhall, and the Conſtable.
There cannot be a Myſtery in a Trade,
But they muſt peepe into it. Mercileſſe varlets,
That know how many fall by our occupation,
And yet would haue their Venery for nothing.
A chambermayd can't haue a Ruffe to ſet,
But they muſt bee poking in it;
Now they haue brought vs vnder contribution,
They vex vs more then the Venetians doe
The whole Corporation of Curtezans:
But we muſt giue good words, ſhew them a roome.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: There's hot ſeruice within, I heare the Muskets
Play from the Rampiers. I am valiant,
And will venter vpon the very mouthes of them.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: Mr. Ardelio, you haue beene a ſtranger.
You are growne rich of late.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: Yes ſomewhat purſy for want of exerciſe.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: Well, I was wont to put in for a gameſter.
But now I am quite thruſt out of all play.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: We were wont to be your ſubiects to worke on,
And ſince you ſcorne vs, yet you cannot ſay,
But you haue found good dealing at our hands.

sp.speaker: 2. Whore.
sp.l: We haue bin alwaies bent to your worſhips will
And forward to helpe you on at all times.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: Truely ſir you know,
I keepe as good creatures at liuery,
And as cheape too, as any poore ſinner
Of my profeſſion.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: Haſt thou ere a morſell,
That is not tainted, or flye blowne?

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: Indeede I haue
So much adoe to keepe my family ſound,
You would wonder at it▪ and ſuch as are ſo,
They are taken vp preſently. But I haue one,
I dare commend to you, for wind and limme.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.p: Come, let me haue her then.

sp.speaker: Miſcel.
sp.l: Its ſtrange there is no more attendance giuen,
To vſher in a man of my quality.
Are you the Gouerneſſe of this Cinqueport, Lady?

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: The fortreſſe, ſir, is mine, and none come here,
But pay me cuſtome.

sp.speaker: Miſcel.
sp.l: Haſt thou nere a Pilot,
Or man of warre to conduct a man ſafe
Into thy Harbour? there be roagues abroade.
Piraticall varlets that would pillage mee.

sp.speaker: Miſcel.
sp.p: I thought at firſt, you would haue bard my entrance.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: I doe not vſe the faſhions of thoſe Countries,
That keepe a ſtranger out foure weekes at ſea,
To know if hee bee ſound. I make no ſcruple,
But giue free traffique to all Nations.
If you haue payd your due, you may put in,
There is the way, Ile follow preſently.
I thinke our ſouldiers are all come, lets in
And ſet the watch.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Stay punke, make roome for vs,
That haue aduanc'd our banners to thy walls,
Paſt all the pikes, the perdues, and the Centries.
Tis a good Omen, whers Bellona there,
And the daughters of Mars, thoſe braue Girles?
We are come to pay our homage to their ſmockes.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: Nay, if you are vnruly, we ſhall tame you.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Feare not, wee are tributaries, punke.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: Sir, doe you ſpeake with no more reuerence
To me? it ſeemes you know me not

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: I ſhall
Endeauour to preſerue thy dignity,
Art thou that braue Hyppolite, that gouernes
This troupe of Scythians? Speake, Orsthya,
My Menalippe, my Antiope
Wee are ſworne vaſſals to your petticoates.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: Did you attempt but the leaſt iniury,
There be in readines, would vindicate
The wrongs, and credit of my houſe.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: I know
Thy power, punke, and do ſubmit me, punke,
Tam Marti, quam Ʋeneri. Tis thy Motto, punke.

sp.speaker: Caprit.
sp.p: Would I could tell how to get out againe.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: How came you in? haue you performd all duties?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: I threw thy Cerberus a ſleepy Morſell,
And payd thy Charon for my waftage ouer.
And I haue a golden ſprig for my Proſerpine.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Nay I do honour
Thee, and thy houſe, and all thy vermine in't.
And thou doſt well to ſtand vpon thy guard,
Spight of the ſtatutes. Tis a Caſtle this,
A Fort, a Metrapolitan bawdy houſe.
A Cynoſarges, ſuch as Hercules
Built in the honour of his pedegree,
For entertainment of the baſt ard iſſue
Of the bold Spartan.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: You haue ſayd enough, ſir.
And for requitall, I will ſhew you in,
Where you ſhall read the titles, and the prices.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: But here's a brother of mine is ſomewhat baſhfull:
I'd faine deliuer him to thy diſcipline.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: What, is he baſhfull? that's a fault indeed.
Come hither, chops, you muſt not be ſo ſhamefac'd?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Loe you there, ſir, you ſhall come forth in print▪
March on, my Calypſo, come ſir, follow your colours.
You ſhall haue the leading of the firſt title,

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Put it on your face.
Now they are houſ • , Ile watch their comming forth,
And fright them in the forme of a Conſtable,
If that ſucceeds well, then Ile change the perſon,
To a Iuſtice of peace, and you ſhall act
My clarke Antolicus. They ſay an officer
Dares not appeare about the Gates: Ile try it.
For I haue made one drunke, and got his ſtaffe.
Which I will vſe with more authority,
Then Mercury his all-commanding rod,
To charme their ſteps, that none ſhall paſſe this way;
Without examination. There ſtalkes one,
Ile firſt know what he is; now they drop away,
As if they leapt out from the Troian horſe;
This is the Autumne of the night: who goes there?

sp.speaker: Antol.
sp.p: Friend, or foe, come before the Conſtable,

sp.speaker: Ardel.
sp.l: And't pleaſe you Sir, I haue
Been wayting on my neece, home to her lodging.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Why, is your Neece a Leagerer, aſuttler,
Or Laundreſſe to this Fort?

sp.speaker: Ardel.
sp.l: No, and it like you,
Shee lyes without the campe.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: You lye like a Pimpe.
You are an Apple-ſquire, a Rat, and a Ferret.
I ſaw you bolt out from that Conney-berry.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Out of the wind of mee what do you thinke,
You can put out the eyes of a gorcrow?
Fob mee off ſo, the Conſtable, that haue
The pariſh ſtock of witt in my hands? I am glad,
That I haue got you from your couert. You ſhall
Bee learcht, you ſhall along with me ſir.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: No farther then to priſon, where you ſhall pay,
But forty ſhillings for noctiuagation.

sp.speaker: Ardel.
sp.l: I am vndone then. There are forty old ſcores,
I owe in Towne, will follow after mee.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.p: What are you? whats your name?

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: A Lords ſeruant.

sp.speaker: Ardel.
sp.l: Alas, a veniall ſinne, wee vſe to learne it,
When wee come firſt to be pages.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.p: Stand by, ther's one has got a clap too.

sp.speaker: Miſcel.
sp.p: The ſhirt of Hersuſes was not ſo hot.

sp.speaker: Snarle.
sp.p: Ther's one ſure has beene hurt with a Gronieado.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: No body. My ſenſes fayle mee then, who iſt?
What man are you?

sp.speaker: Miſcel.
sp.l: No man, you are deceiu'd,
I can not find I am a man, that part
Is dead, wherein I once was an Achilles:

sp.speaker: Miſcel.
sp.p: I can not go, I haue loſt my nerues.

sp.speaker: Antol.
sp.p: You ſhall be carryed to the Iayle then▪

sp.speaker: Miſcel.
sp.l: Fitter
For an Hoſpitall. I am condemned already
To fluxes, and dyer drinkes.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.p: Who's that Heronimoes ſonnes ghoſt in the Garden?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: O Mr. Conſtable, wee haue beene ſo vſde,
As neuer two aduentrous Gentlemen
In the hands of their enemies.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Let mee take breath: I am at the laſt gaſpe.
We haue eskapt from the denne of the Cyclops,
There was one ranne a ſpit againſt my eyes.

sp.speaker: Caprit.
sp.l: Amongſt the reſt, there was a blinke-eyed woman
Set a great dog vpon mee.

sp.speaker: Trm.
sp.l: They haue ſpoyld vs
Of our cloakes, our hats, our ſwords, and our money.

sp.speaker: Snarle.
sp.p: Your wits, and credit were both loſt before.

sp.speaker: Caprit.
sp.p: No, wee had not our wits about vs then.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Good ſir, let's thinke on ſome reuenge, call vp
The Gentlemen prentiſes, and make a Shrouetueſday.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.p: By no meanes, I muſt ſuppreſſe all violence.

sp.speaker: Caprit.
sp.l: My brother talkt of building of a ſconce,
And ſtraight they ſeazd our cloakes for the reckoning.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: There I loſt my hat and ſword in the reskew.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: And whilſt ſome ſtroue to hold my hands,
The other diu'd in my pockets. I am ſure,
There was a fellow with a tand face, whoſe breath
Was growne ſulphurous with oathes and tobacco,
Puft terror in my face, I ſhal neuer bee
Mine owne man againe.

sp.speaker: 1 Who.
sp.p: Twere a good deed to haue made them ſwim the mote.

sp.speaker: 2 Who.
sp.p: I, to haue ſiript them, and ſent them out naked.

sp.speaker: 1 Who.
sp.l: Let's ſally out, and fetch them in againe.
Then call a court on them for falſe alarums.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Flye from their rage, ſir; they are worſe then Harpyes,
They'll teare vs, as the Thracians did Orpheus,
Whoſe Muſicke, though it charmd the powers of Hell,
Could not bee heard amongſt theſe. Mr. Ardelio
And Miſcellanio, I ioy to ſee you,
Though ill met here.

sp.speaker: Miſcel.
sp.l: Signiour Trimalchio,
Sir you muſt pardon me. I can not ſtoope.
I haue the Grincums in my backe, I feare
Will ſpoyle my courtſhip.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Mr. Ardelio,
Who would expected to haue met you here?

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: Nay, who would not expect it? tis my haunt.
I loue it, as a pigeon, loues a ſalt-pit.

sp.speaker: Miſcel.
sp.l: O mee! my ſcholler too how came he hither?
I did not meane t'impart this myſtery.
How could hee find it out?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: His owne Minerua,
And my helpt, ſir.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Marry, before a Iuſtice,
To anſwere for your ryot.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.p: I can not diſpence with it.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.p: Not before next ſeſſions. Bring them away.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: Was euer ſuch a treacherous plot intended,
Againſt our State, and dignity?

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Had this
Paſt with impunity, they might haue ſworne,
Vengeance had r • nne the country.

sp.speaker: 1. Whore.
sp.l: But I hope,
They haue no cauſe to boaſt their victory,

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Now by this aire, as I am a true ſould • er,
Bred vnder, and deuoted to your Banne,
But that your pitty did prenent my rage,
They ſhould haue knowne no quarter, for this brow
Brookes no affronts.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: Wee'l haue a ſtone grauen with characters.
To intimate your proweſſe.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: No, my deare Gorgons,
I will not haue my ſame wander without
The precincts of your Caſtell: tis enough
It can be ſheltred heere, within theſe walls.
And to recount with your acknowledgements,
What this Fort owes to my protection.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: Captaine, wee muſt confeſſe you are our Guardian.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Then let mee ſacrifice vnto my humour.
All you this night, ſhall be at my diſpoſing,
To drinke and dra • , tis the fault of your fortune
That do profeſſe this trade, t'haue ſomebody,
To ſpend your purchaſe on, tis my decree,
What others ryot, you ſhould waſte on me.

div.head: Actus 4. Scene 4.
div.stage: Agurtes like a Iuſtice of peace. Antelicus his Clarke.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Then let mee ſee
How I can act it: do I looke like a Iuſtice?

sp.speaker: Antol.
sp.p: As fearefull as an Aſſe in a Lyons skinne, ſir.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Here I begin my ſtate. Suppoſe mee now
Come downe the ſtaires, out of the dining roome,
Into the hall, and thus I begin. Briſco.
Call Briſco my Clarke.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Reach mee my enſigne of authority,
My ſtaffe I meane. Fy, fy, how dull you are,
And incompoſed? Now ſet me in my chaire,
That I may looke like a Cathedrall Iuſtice,
That knew, what belongs to an Aſſignanimus,
And Dedimus poteſtatis. Nay, though we are
O • the peace, wee can giue Priſcian a knocke.
Let mee alone now to determine cauſes,
As free from error as the Pope. Old Minos,
And Rhadmanth, are not ſo skilldith vrne,
As I am in the ſtatutes. I haue them ad vngue •
Now if they enter, at their perill bee it.
How doſt thou like my action?

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Let them come in.
sp.stage: Enter Snarle like a Conſtable. Trimalchio, Capritio, M • ſcellanio, Ardelio.
sp.l: Now Mr Conſtable,
I muſt commend your diligence. Come hither.

sp.speaker: Snarl.
sp.l: Sir I haue brough foure men before your Worſhip,
I found laſt night, at midnight, in the ſtreets,
Rayſing a tumult.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Briſco, bee ready to take
Their examination. Good: you found foure men,
At midnight. Whoſe men are they?

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: So it ſeemes by your Liueries.
Write that downe; firſt they ſay, they are their owne men.

sp.speaker: Ardel.
sp.p: Sir, by your fauour, I am not my owne man.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: I thought they would not all bee in one tale,
I knew I ſhould find them tripping, and I
Once come to ſift them. You are not your owne man.
It argues you are drunke. Write his confeſſion,
Ex os tuum te iudico: perge Mr. Conſtable.

sp.speaker: Snarle.
sp.l: I hold it fit, your Worſhip ſhould examine
What they did there ſo late,

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: What did you there
So late?

sp.speaker: Miſcel.
sp.p: Good Iuſtice Eccho, wee had buſines.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Record, they ſay they had buſines. They ſhall know.
That I am Iudge of Record, and what I do
Record, ſhal ſtand, and they ſhal haue no power
To plead not guilty in a Scire facias,
By a Recognifance. I haue my termes.

sp.speaker: Ardel
sp.p: Good your Worſhip, giue vs not ſuch hard words.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Tis almoſt as hard vſage as the Leager.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.p: Then you came from the Leager?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: You may reade
Some aduentures in our habit, wee haue ſeene,
And taſted the experience of the warres.

sp.speaker: Miſcel.
sp.l: They haue made me of another religion,
I muſt turne Iew, I thinke, and bee circum • iſed.
I may be any thing, now I ſhall loſe a Limme.
I may goe ſeeke my penſion with the ſouldiers.
But ti • no matter, I'll turne valiant,
And fight with the ſtumpe.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: You are a fighter then.
T • is doth appeare to mee, to bee a ryot.
What thinke you, Mr. Conſtable?

sp.speaker: Snarle.
sp.l: I know not
What you meane, but I meane as your Worſhip meanes.
I did perceiue they had beene quarelling.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Why then 'twas an affray, a ſudden affray,
Directly againſt the State of Northampton.
The Decimo tertio of Harry the fourth cleares the doubt.
How doe you trauerſe this? what doe you anſwere?

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: We make a queſtion, by your Worſhips fauour,
Vnder correction, whether that which was
Done vnder forraine powers, in forraine Lands,
Be puniſhable heere or no.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: Tis a prouince by it ſelfe, a priuiledg'd place,
A ſtrong corporation, and has factions
In Court and Citty.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Is inhabited
With furies, that do multiply like Hydra:
An army of diſeaſes can't ſuppreſſe them,
Beſides their many fallings t'other way.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: I ſhould be loth t'infringe their liberties,
Ile ſend you to betryed, from whence you came then.

sp.speaker: Caprit.
sp.l: O good your Worſhip, hang vs vp at home firſt,
Let vs indure the racke or the ſtrappado,
We do ſubmit vs to your Worſhips cenſure.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.p: Haue you prouided ſureties for the peace then?

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: More neede to prouide ſomethings for my belly.
I thinke they meane to keepe me for a race.
I am falne away quite, I was like a hogſhead.
Now I amable to runne thorow my hoopes.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Whats he that halts before 〈◊〉 doe you mocke me?
Tis ill halting before acripple, 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Miſcel.
sp.l: This ſore againſt my will, I can not helpe it.
Would I could runne away with halfe my teeth.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Can't a man haue the venerable gowt,
Or the bone-ache, but you muſt imitate him?

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Mocke your fellow rogues.
I am none of thoſe, that rayſd my fortunes with
Fiddling and Tobacco. Make his Mittimus.

sp.speaker: Snarle.
sp.p: And't pleaſe you ſir, here's one has brought a Letter.

sp.speaker: Snarle.
sp.l: He ſayes, from one Miſtriſſe Milleſcent,
The contents will informe you.

stage.p:
NOble ſir, I am ſorry to intereſt my vnſtay • d honour in the patronage of offendors, orto abuſe the credit I haue with you, in ſtopping the courſe of Iustice againſt them, whoſe youthfull licenciouſneſſe, would pollute the pen of a Lady to excuſe it. On the other part, J hold it the betraying of a virgins ſweete diſpoſition, to withdraw her fauours, where ſhe has once plac'd them, although there be ſome want of deſert. I muſt confeſse tis an Antipathy to my nature, to ſee any Gentleman ſuffer, when I may preuent it. Howſoeuer I haue found a diſreſpect from him, yet I forget it. For anger abides in the boſomes of women, as ſnow on the ground: where it is ſmooth and leuell, it fals quickly off, but remaynes where it is rough and vneuen. That this may appeare to bee true, I would intreate you to diſmiſſe thoſe two Gentlemen and their aſſociates, Mr. Trimalchio, and Capritio, whoſe ryotous looſeneſse has made them obnoxious to your cenſure, and my ſuſpicion. Thus
not doubting the ſucceſſe of my letter, I reſt in your fauour as you may preſume on mine, and your true friend,

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: This Lady, that has writ in your behalfe,
Is one I honour.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: How •• ould ſhe heare of it?

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: It •••• es, your fault is quickly blowne abroad.
〈…〉 rather ſeale a Nouerint vniuerſi,
For a thouſand pound ſtale commodities,
Then thee ſhould know of it.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: As for you two,
You may pay your fees and depart, you haue
Your manumiſſion, or this Ladies ſake.
Maſter. Conſtable, you are diſcharg'd, and you may
Goe along with them and receiue their fees.

sp.speaker: Miſ.
sp.l: Though I ſay nothing, yet I ſmell ſomething:
A Lady ſend a letter? Shee is, in loue
With me, Ile pawne my life, and I nere knew it.
I'le get my backe well, and goe viſit her.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: Now I haue got my teeth at liberty,
And they ere tye me to the racke againe,
Let me be choakt.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Well, I perceiue you are
A fauourite to this Lady. Whats your name?

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.p: Two ancient names in Camden, Of what country?

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: The Capritios of Norfolke.
I thinke we ſhall bee kin anon. My mother
Was a Capritie, and of that houſe;
Are you alyed vnto this Lady?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: No ſir.
But I haue formerly beene entertain'd
As a poore • utor to her graces fauour.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: I finde by that, you are a man of faſhion.
And would you then?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Nay good ſir, doe not chide.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Yes, I muſt tell you, that you were to blame,
Hauing ſo faire a fortune before you, to wrong
A Lady of her ſpirit; ſo rich, and faire,
Of vn • ep • ooued chaſtity, and one
So high in birth, nay 'tis not poſſible
To ſpeake her vertues, and preſent your ſelfe
So • umpiſhly, nay perhaps fill her bed
Full of diſeaſes.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Good ſir, ſay no more.
I am a • raycor, I haue kild a man,
Committed ſacriledge. Let her ſeeke reuenge
For theſe, or if leſſe puniſhment will ſerue:
To haue me beaten, Ile runne naked to her.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: I will not preſſe a good nature ſo farre:
You two ſhall ſtay and dine with me. Ile ſend
My coach for your Miſtris, it ſhall goe hard:
But I will make you friends, before we part.

sp.speaker: Fauſt.
sp.l: Now let mee bid you welcome from the warres,
Laden with conqueſt, and the golden fleece
Of honour, which like Iaſon, you haue brought
T'inrich your Country, now indebted to you.
Had it not beene a pitty ſuch a talent
Of vertue ſhould be loſt or ill imployd?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Lady, you are a good Phyſicion,
It was your counſel wrought' this miracle,
Beyond the power of Aeſculapius:
For when my mind was ſtupified, and loſt
In the purſuit of pleaſures: all my body
Torne, and diſſected with cloſe vanityes,
You haue collected me anew to life:
And now I come to you, with as chaſte thoughts,
As they were firſt adulterous, and yeeld
A due ſubmiſſion for the wrong I did
Both to your ſelfe, and ſex.

sp.speaker: Fauſt.
sp.l: Sir. for my part,
You haue your pardon.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: You were borne to quit mee.

sp.speaker: Fude.
sp.l: But when you know the Authour of your freedome,
You'll thanke her more.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Who? not Fauſtina? ſhee told me ſo indeed,
Her name was Fauſtina. Let mee looke vpon her,
As on the picture of all goodneſſe, engrauen
By a celeſtiall finger, ſhall weare out:
A marble character. I knew her not,
I am glad there is aſcien of our ftock.
Can beare ſuch fruit as this, ſo ripe in vertue.
Where haue you liu'd recluſe? you were betrothd
To one Fidelio; but croſt by your father.
I haue heard good reports of the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Fauſt.
sp.l: I neuer knew you flatter any man
Vnto his face before.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Vnto his face?
Where is hee?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I am tranſported, rauiſht: giue mee leaue
Good gods, to entertaine with reuerence,
So great a comfort. Let mee firſt embrace you.
Great ioyes, like greifes, are ſilent. Looſe mee now,
And let me make you faſt. Here ioyne your hands,
Which no age ſhall vnty. Let happineſſe
Diſtill from you, as the Arabian gummes,
To bleſſe your iſſue.

sp.speaker: Fidel.
sp.l: Now I hope, ſweet Lady,
The time has put a period to your vow.

sp.speaker: Fauſt.
sp.l: Tis ended now, and you may take a comfort,
That I could tye my ſelfe to ſuch a law.
For you may hope thereby, I ſhall obſerue you
With no leſſe ſtrict obedience.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: And for her dowry, I will treble it,
Heere Sanrle is come to be a witneſſe to it.

sp.speaker: Snarle.
sp.l: My Lord Philautus, if I may preſume
To congratulate your Honours ſafe returne,
I muſt confeſſe, I doe it with my heart,
And all your friends long to participate
Your happy preſence.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Thankes both to them and thee.

sp.speaker: Snarle.
sp.l: Maſter Fidelio, no leſſe to you.
I ſee you happy in your Miſtris fauour:
And thats as much, as I can wiſh to you.

sp.speaker: Fidel.
sp.l: You haue bin alwaies priuy to my counſell
Aske me no queſtions now, I ſhall reſolue you
When we come in.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: How fares our Campe at home,
Trimalchio, and the reſt?

sp.speaker: Snarle.
sp.l: I haue beene buſie,
In proiecting for them, they muſt all bee married.
I haue ſeene the interlude of the Leager:
And we haue playd the Iuſtice, and the Conſtable:
I will not prepoſſeſſe you with the ſport,
But I will ſhew you ſuch aſcene of laughter.

sp.speaker: Snarle.
sp.l: Your ſeruant Ardelio.
Tis the notoriouſt mixture of a villaine,
That euer yet was bred vnder the dunghill
Of ſeruitude. Hee has more whores at command,
Then you haue horſes. He has ſtables for them,
His priuate vawting houſes.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Diſcharge him the houſe.
Take his accounts and office, and diſpoſe them.

sp.speaker: Snarle.
sp.p: Euer your Lordſhips true and faythfull ſeruant.

sp.speaker: Milleſ.
sp.p: When was my Father, and the Captaine heere?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: They are plotting abroad, I hope to ſee you ſhortly
Honeſtly marryed, and then turne vertuous.

sp.speaker: Milleſ.
sp.l: Tis the courſe of the world now, Margery.
But yet I feare, I haue got ſuch a tricke,
When I was young, that I ſhall neuer leaue it.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: What helpe then? the poore Gentleman muſt ſuffer,
Good Trimalchio: tis his fate.

sp.speaker: Milleſ.
sp.l: I am thinking,
What I ſhall do with him, when I am marryed.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: What do other women do with their huſbands?
Bring him vp in obedience, make him beſides
An implement to ſaue your reputation.
Let him not preſſe into your company
Without permiſſion, you muſt pretend,
You are aſham'd of him. Let him not eate,
Nor lye with you, vnleſſe he pay the hire
Of a new gowne, or petticote: liue with him,
As if you were his neighbour, onely neere him,
In that you hate his friends: and when you pleaſe.
To ſhew the power you carry ouer him,
Send him before on foot, and you come after
With your coach and foure horſes.

sp.speaker: Milleſ.
sp.l: Tis fitting ſo
Hoſt now what peece of motion haue wee heere
Would you ſpeake with any body?

sp.speaker: Miſcel.
sp.l: My buſineſſe,
Is to the Lady Milleſcent.

sp.speaker: Miſcel.
sp.l: To you then I derect m • apologie.
It ſeemes your eye with approbation,
Has glanc'd vpon my perſon. I proteſt
I neuer was ſo dull in the conſtruction
Of any Ladyes fauour in my life:
I am aſham'd of my error.

sp.speaker: Milleſ.
sp.l: In what, ſir?
I can not call to mind that ere I ſaw you.

sp.speaker: Miſcel.
sp.l: You haue beene ſtill too modeſt to conceale it.
That was not my fault: you did ill to ſtriue
To hide the flames of loue, they muſt haue vent:
Tis not the walls of fleſh can hold them in.

sp.speaker: Milleſ.
sp.l: What riddles haue we heere? that I ſhould loue you?
I would not haue you thinke ſo wel of your ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Perhaps hee has ſome petition to deliuer,
Or would deſire your letter to ſome Lord.

sp.speaker: Miſce.
sp.l: I know not how, ſure I was ſtupifyed,
I haue ere now gheſt at a Ladyes mind,
Only by the warbling of her Luteſtring,
Kiſſing her hand, or wagging of her feather,
And ſuffer you to pine for my imbraces,
And not conceiue it?

sp.speaker: Milleſ.
sp.l: Pray bee pacified.
This fellow will perſwade me, I am in loue.

sp.speaker: Miſcel.
sp.l: Lady, you haue tooke notice of my worth
Let it not repent you. Bee not ſtubborne
Towards your happineſſe. You haue endur'd
Too much already for my ſake, you ſhall ſee,
Pitty can melt my heart. I take no delight,
To haue a Lady languiſh for my lioe.
I am not made of flint as you ſuſpect mee.

sp.speaker: Milleſ.
sp.l: I would thou wert conuerted to a pillar,
For a memoriall of this impudence.

sp.speaker: Miſcel.
sp.l: You ſhall know what tis to tempt me heereafter,
When I ſhall let you periſh for your folly.
I came to remunerate the curteſie,
I receiu'd from your Ladiſhip.

sp.speaker: Miſcel.
sp.p: I muſt acknowledge my ſelfe bound to you

sp.speaker: Miſcel.
sp.l: Your Letter to the Iuſtice, Lady,
It freed me from the pounces of thoſe varlets,
When I was vnder the gripe of the Law.
I know, the onely motiue was your loue.

sp.speaker: Milleſ.
sp.l: I cry you mercy, were you one of them
That drew Trimalchio to thoſe idle courſes?
I am aſhamed of the benefit, leaue mee
That I may not ſee the cauſe of my ſorrow:
But 'tis no matter, we ſhall leaue you firſt.

sp.speaker: Miſcel.
sp.l: They ſhall find, I am no man to be ſlighted,
And that ſhee has miſplac'd her affection.
When I haue wrackt the wrongs on my corriuall,
Trimalchio, looke to thy ſelfe, were hee remou'd,
There might be hopes, my valour ſhall make known
There is a difference. Ile ſtraight to the tauerne:
And when I once am hot with good Canary,
I pronounce him dead that affronts my fury.

sp.speaker: Ardelio.
sp.l: Turn'd out of ſeruice the next turne will be
Vnder the Gallows, and haue a Ballad made of me,
The corruption of a caſheer'd Seruing-man,
Is the generation of a thiefe. I ſcare,
My fate poynts me not out to ſo good fortune.
My bulke will not ſerue me to take a purſe.
The beſt thing I am fit for, is a tap • ter,
Or elſe get a wench of mine owne, and ſell
Bottell Ale and Tobacco, that's my refuge
They tearmd me paraſite, 'tis a myſtery
Is like a familiar, that leaues a man
When he is neere his execution.
I haue no power to flatter my ſelfe now,
I might haue gone a wooing to ſome widdow,
And had his countenance, but now the tenants
Looke like their Bacon, ruſtily, vpon me.
What, Ieffery! thou art the comfort of my woes:
Welcome, good Ieffry.

sp.speaker: Ieff.
sp.l: Very wel, ſir.
Lockt in a Cypreſſe cheſt, for feare of Moths.

sp.speaker: Aed.
sp.p: And all the other furniture good Ieffry.

sp.speaker: Ieff.
sp.p: They are kept ſafe, and well ary'd for your Worſhip.

sp.speaker: Ardel.
sp.l: Thanks, good Ieffry. I were in a ſweet caſe,
If I had not conuayd ſomethings away,
To maintaine mee hereafter.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: I may go ſet vp bils now for my liuing,
Cry Vineger vp and downe the ſtreets; or fiſh
At blacke Fryers ſtayres; or ſit againſt
A wall, with a library of ballads before mee.

sp.speaker: Ieff.
sp.p: You are not out of ſeruice.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: Turnd a grazing,
In the wide Common of the world, Ieffry.

sp.speaker: Ieff.
sp.l: Then are my hopes at beſt, I haue no reaſon
To care for him any longer; a word with you.
What furniture do you meane?

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: Thoſe that I ſent,
The beds, and hangings.

sp.speaker: Ardel.
sp.p: I hope you will not vſe mee ſo.

sp.speaker: Ieff.
sp.l: Your owne words.
I muſt make the beſt benefit of my place:
You know, tis not an age to bee honeſt in.
Tis the only high-way vnto pouerty.
I know not how, I do not fancy you
Of late.

sp.speaker: Arde.
sp.l: I choſe thee for thy knauiſh looke.
And now thou haſt requited mee: of all
My euils, thou art the worſt.

sp.speaker: Ieff.
sp.l: No fayth, ſir.
You haue a worſe commodity at my houſe.
But you may ſaue the charges of a writ.
Ile ſend her you without reprieue or bayle.
I doe you that fauour.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.p: No, you may keepe her ſtill.

sp.speaker: Ieff.
sp.l: My thinkes you are much deiected with your fall,
I finde an alteration in your face.
You looke like an Almanacke of laſt yeeres date.
Or like your liuery cloake, of two yeeres wearing.
Worſe then the ſmoaky wall of a bawdy houſe.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.p: Villaine, doſt thou inſult on me?

sp.speaker: Ieff
sp.l: No fayth ſir,
Al • ſſe, tis not within the reach of man,
To countermine your plots.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: Well, ſlaue, becauſe
Ile rid my hands of thee, Ile giue thee a ſhare.

sp.speaker: Ieff.
sp.l: You muſt haue none, without lawfull proceeding.
And that I know, you dare not.

sp.speaker: Snarle.
sp.l: But I dare.
Haue you beene partners all this while in miſchiefe,
And now fall out, who ſhall bee the moſt knaue?

sp.speaker: Snarle.
sp.l: I meane to ſearch your houſe
For ammunition, no otherwiſe,
Which I ſuſpect you ſend vnto the Leager.

sp.speaker: Ieff.
sp.l: Sir I haue nothing there, but one crackt piece
Belongs to this Gentleman, can doe no ſeruice.
She is ſpoyld in the bore.

sp.speaker: Snarle.
sp.l: Wee'l haue her new caſt.
Come, bring them away.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: Nay good ſir, you know,
That I was lately quit before a Iuſtice.
And if I fall in a relapſe.

sp.speaker: Snarle.
sp.l: Al's one
To me, but you muſt ſatisfie the Law.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.p: Well then, I know the worſt of it.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.p: Maſter Trimalchio, 'tis an age ſince I ſaw you.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: I was nere out of towne.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Not out of towne?
We ſought you about all the Ordinaries,
Tauernes and Bawdyhouſes, we could imagine
You euer haunted.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: You might haue found vs then.

sp.speaker: Antol.
sp.p: Nay more, we inquir'd at the Play-houſes.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.p: 'Twas once in my minde, to haue had you cryed.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Well, ſhall I tell you, Captaine?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: This Gentleman and I
Haue paſt through purgatory, ſince I ſaw you.
If I ſhould tell you all the paſſages
At the Leager.

sp.speaker: Antol.
sp.l: Thither we came to meete you,
And you were gone.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: 'Tis ſuch a ſtory
Would fill a Chronicle.

sp.speaker: Capr.
sp.l: We met with a party of the enemies,
Tooke all we had from vs, and then it coſt vs
Forty ſhillings in fees at the Iuſtices.

sp.speaker: Capr.
sp.l: The old boy and I
Grew to be kin at laſt.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: He made me ſure
To my miſtris, before we parted.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Honeſt Ardelio,
And Miſellanio, wee were all together
In rebellion, and quit by a Letter,
That came from my miſtreſſe.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Iſt poſſible?
And Miſcellanio turne traytor?

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Would haue your miſtreſſe from you, thinkes the Letter
Was ſent for his ſake.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: That I am ſure hee does not.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.p: Threatens, and ſweares that he wil fight for her.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: If hee bee weary of his life, hee may.
Why what can hee pretend to her?

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: I know not,
What has paſt betweene them, but I am ſure,
He has beene practiſing at the Fencing ſchoole,
To get a trick to kill you.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Hee kill mee!
I'll kill him firſt. I fight by Geometry.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Yes ſir, heere I hold
My Rapier, marke mee, in a diameter
To my body; thats the center, conceiue mee.

sp.speaker: Antol.
sp.p: Your body is the center, very good.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: And my hilt, part of the circumference.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Which hilt is bigger then my body.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Yes at ſuch a diſtance.
And hee ſhall neuer hit mee, whilſt hee liues.

sp.speaker: Antol.
sp.p: Where did you learne this? At the leager?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: No.
No by this light: it is my owne inuention.
I learnt it in my trauels.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Very ſtrange:
You are a ſcholler.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: No: I would not bee
• uſpected of ſuch a crime for a Million.
But tis no ſinne to know Geometry;
And by that, I can tel wee ſhal nere fight.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: I'l ſhew you in Geometry,
Two paralels can neuer meet: now wee two
Being paralels, for ſo wee are, that is
Equal in wit and valour, can neuer meet.
And if wee neuer meet, wee ſhal nere fight.

sp.speaker: Antol.
sp.p: To proue your axiome falſe, ſee where hee comes▪

sp.speaker: Miſcel.
sp.l: Hang thee bluſtring ſonne
Of Aeolus, defy me! I'll tye vp thy breath
In bags, and ſell it for a penny an ounce.

sp.speaker: Capri.
sp.l: Sure, this is the ſecond part of the Leager.
Twere beſt for me, to hide mee in my cabin.

sp.speaker: Miſcel.
sp.p: Vnleſſe you'l haue her tane away by force.

sp.speaker: Antol.
sp.p: I ſee, this cannot be ended without bloud.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: I am afrayd he comes with the blacke art.

sp.speaker: Antol.
sp.p: How you afrayd? do not ſay ſo for ſhame.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Hee has layne with an old witch at Sweden.
And is growne ſticke free.

sp.speaker: Antol.
sp.p: Fy that you ſhall ſay ſo.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: I'll be reſolu'd of that before I fight.

sp.speaker: Antol.
sp.p: Why, do you thinke that witches haue ſuch power?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: I marry do I, I haue knowne one of them,
Do more then that, when her husband has followed
Strange women, ſhee has turnd him into a Bezer,
And made him bite out his owne ſtones.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: I'll tell you another as ſtrange as that, of one
When a Vintner has ſent her but ill wine,
Shee has conuerted him into a Frog.
And then coniur'd him into one of his butts,
Where hee has liued twelue moneths vpon the lees,
And when his old gheſts chance to come to ſee him,
Hee has croackt to them, out at the bunghole.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: There was a Lawyer
That ſpoke againſt one of them at the barre.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Turnd him into a Ram,
And ſtill that Ram retaynes his profeſſion,
Has many Clients, and pleads cauſes as well
As ſome Lawyers in Weſtminſter.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.l: Do you thinke,
That hee has had recourſe to any ſuch?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: I know not, but tis good to bee miſtruſtfull.
Hee may haue aduantage in the encounter.

sp.speaker: Miſcel.
sp.p: There ſhe comes, winne her, and weare her.

sp.speaker: Milleſ.
sp.l: Hold your hands.
I'll haue no bloud a prologue to my wedding.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Nay then haue at you. Hold mee not, I ſay •
I am as fierce as hee.

sp.speaker: Milleſ.
sp.l: Bee pacified.
I thought you had beene both bound to the peace.

sp.speaker: Antol.
sp.l: Lady, it ſeemes, that theſe two Gentlemen
Do ſtand in competition for your loue.

sp.speaker: Milleſ.
sp.l: Mr. Trimalchio, I confeſſe, has beene
A former ſuitor, but with his ill carriage,
He has thus long preuented his good fortune.

sp.speaker: Antol.
sp.p: Then let mee make a motion.

sp.speaker: Antol.
sp.p: Will they both ſtand to it?

sp.speaker: Autol.
sp.p: Then let the Lady diſpoſe of her ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Shee is mine already. I am ſure to her,
Before a Iuſtice.

sp.speaker: Miſcel.
sp.l: I will haue no woman,
Againſt her will.

sp.speaker: Milleſ.
sp.l: No ſir, nor you ſhall not,
Since you are ſo peremptory, on your words then
That hee ſhall ſing a Palinodium,
And recant his ill courſes, I aſſume
My Loue Trimalehio.

sp.speaker: Capri.
sp.p: Do wee take, or are we taken?

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Who's that, Capritio? where haue you beene?
Come your wayes forth, and lay hands on the ſpoyle.
Goe lead away that Lady by the hand.
Now you may take occaſion by the foretop,
Aduance your owne predominant the better,
And march away,

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Come, let vs to the Church.

sp.speaker: Miſcel.
sp.p: And what muſt I do now? bee laught at?

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Would you
Hazard your ſelfe, for one that cares not for you?
You may be glad you ſcap't. Recall your ſelfe.
Were not you formerly engagd?

sp.speaker: Miſcel.
sp.l: Fayth we haue toy'd
In ieſt ſometime.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Let it bee now in earneſt.
Make her amends. I know ſhee loues you.

sp.speaker: Miſcel.
sp.l: Well.
I will haue her, and ſtand vp for my portion,
With the reſt of my tribe.

div.head: Scena vltima.

sp.speaker: Snarle
sp.l: Stay heere a little, they are gone to Church,
And will returne in couples. Firſt, Trimalchio,
That Gyant in conceit, thinkes he is ma • cht
To ſome great heire, but ſhall imbrace a cloud
In ſtead of Iuno. Then her waiting woman,
Her Iris, reflects vpon Capritio,
And for my piece of fragmentary Courtſhip,
My Miſcellany Gentleman, 'tis his lot
To bee caſt vpon Quartilla with Agurtes
In his old Iuſticeſhip. All theſe march together,
Like the ſeuen deadly ſinnes, and behind them,
Comes Antolicus, the clarke of the company.

div.stage: Trimalchio, Milleſcent. Miſcellanio, Quartilla, Capritio, Margery, Antolicus like a Clarke,

sp.speaker: Antol.
sp.p: Looke you ſir, here they come.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Make roome, me thinkes
You ſhould not ſtop the courſe of Iuſtice ſo.
My Lord Philantus, you are welcome from
The Warres, and I from the Church. I wonder
Who makes the better returne, you haue got
Honour, and ſo haue I. But wher's your wealth?
I can imbrace fiue thouſand pounds, a yeere.
That's nothing with you, I haue no more wit,
Then to be pi'd by pimpes, and marry whoores,
Yet I meane ſhortly to ranke with your honour.
Here is my warrant, I haue promiſd her,
To make her a Counteſſe, but thats nothing with you,
Nay, more then this I can goe on, and leaue
Some aduancement: behind me. Ecce ſignum,

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Tis well, I am glad of your happineſſe,
And much ioy to my brother Capritio,
And his faire ſpouſe.

sp.speaker: Capri.
sp.l: She is according to
My hearts deſire, ſir.

sp.speaker: Snarle.
sp.l: Well, a word with you,
Maſter Trimalchio, and the reſt.

sp.speaker: Snarle.
sp.l: You were as good know it at firſt, as at laſt.
You are not the firſt, that haue beene deceiued.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: In what? my wife? I married her for a mayd.
And whether ſhe be one, or no, I care not.

sp.speaker: Snarle.
sp.l: Nay, ſhould I heare a man that ſhould abuſe her
In that, I would defend her with my ſword.
But ſhe and you muſt call this man your father.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: I ſo ſhe muſt, hee gaue her at the Church.

sp.speaker: Snarl
sp.l: Nay, her owne naturall father, fleſh and bone,
I hope ſhee'l not deny it.

sp.speaker: Milleſ.
sp.l: No indeede, ſir.
I wou'd not liue to be ſo vngracious.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: I muſt acknowledge thee my child, or I
Sho • ld doe thy mother wrong.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: I doe not thinke ſo,
You'l not make me beleeue that I tooke her
For a Lords daughter, and a great heire. Where are
Agurtes and the Captaine to iuſtifie it?
Is hee your father?

sp.speaker: Milleſ.
sp.l: He has euer bred mee:
And I haue alwayes cal'd him ſo. I hope
It is no ſhame: my parentage is honeſt.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Well, if hee bee, tis no diſparagement,
To marry a Iuſtices daughter.

sp.speaker: Snarle.
sp.l: Come, you haue
Beene carryed hood winkt through this buſineſſe.
Nor is the day yet cleere before you. Marke mee;
I'll open but one leafe in all the booke,
And you ſhall ſee the whole diſcouery.
Come ſir, vneaſe.

div.stage: Agurtes and Antolicus pull off there diſguiſes.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Who haue we heere? Agurtes
And the Captaine? Was't you that playd the Iuſtice?
And you his clarke?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Then you are a knot of knaues for your labour.
Now I perceiue that I am playnly guld.

sp.speaker: Capr.
sp.p: I am glad ther's no man cheated but himſelfe.

sp.speaker: Snarle.
sp.l: Your arrow is one of the ſame quiuer too.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Ile none of her by this light.

sp.speaker: Agur.
sp.l: Why, you may chuſe.
And yet I doe not well ſee, how you can chuſe.
She is your wife, and you haue married her,
And muſt allow her meanes to maintayne her.
You may declare your ſelfe vnto the world.
And bee laught at: but keepe your owne counſell,
And who needs know of it?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Beleeue me ſir,
The Gentlewoman is not to be deſpiſde,
Her wit and vertues are dowry ſufficient.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.l: Nay, if you ſay ſo, then muſt I needs loue her:
But by this hand, I thought you would haue jeer'd me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Hold on your courſe, march on as you came in,
And reſt content, ſince fate has thought it fit,
To make your fortunes equall with your wit.
